occurrences.line_text: Whose tender heart the faire Belphebe had,
Of all the bounty, which Belphebe threw
Vntill she came where wonned his Belphebe faire.
The fauour of Belphebe, (as ye heard)
Belphoebe fowle forlorne.
Or in Belphoebe fashioned to bee:
Belphoebe was her name, as faire as Phoebus sunne.
As did Belphoebe, in the bloudy place,
Which seeing faire Belphoebe, gan to feare,
Of this faire virgin, this Belphoebe faire,
The birth of faire Belphoebe and
But to this faire Belphoebe in her berth
She bore Belphoebe, she bore in like cace
And of her selfe her name Belphoebe red:
Whose bridle rung with golden bels and bosses braue.
For hauing filcht her bels, her vp he cast
From bels and iesses, which did let her flight,
And by his belt his booke he hanging had;
And girded with a belt of twisted brake,
That glorious belt did in it selfe containe,
And brought with her fro[m] thence that goodly belt away.
That goodly belt was Cestus hight by name,
Then was that golden belt by doome of all
The belt againe, about her bodie gan it tie.
But Artegall that golden belt vptooke,
About their middles that faire belt to knit;
With an embrodered belt of mickell pride;
Great Belus, Phoeax, and Agenor best;
He wept, and wayld, and false laments belyde,
Gins to abate the brightnesse of his beme,
And griefull pittie priuately bemone.
But to her selfe her sorrow did bemone.
He could no more but her great misery bemone.
Crying in vaine to her, him to bemone;
And still bemoning her vnworthy paine.
Ne euer would to any by-way bend,
Thither Duessa bad him bend his pace:
To yonder same Hierusalem do bend,
To which I meane my wearie course to bend;
Thereto his subtile engins he does bend
When I at her my murdrous blade did bend,
Strong warres they make, and cruell battry bend
Ne euer will it breake, ne euer bend.
All those against that fort did bend their batteries.
And gan himselfe to second battell bend,
Be not too bold; whereto though she did bend
And deadly points at eithers breast to bend,
The warie fowle that spies him toward bend
Till euening, that the Sunne gan downward bend.
Whereof I sorie, yet my selfe did bend,
He should his flale to finall execution bend.
Doe spend my dayes, and bend my carelesse wit
Did bend their speares, and both with equall might
And in his hand a bended bow was seene,
The Eugh obedient to the benders will,
All bard with golden bendes, which were entayld
Which to expresse, he bends his gentle wit,
All bard with double bends, that none could weene
Basted with bends of gold on euery side,
Her mind so well, that to his will she bends
Then to the rest his wrathfull hand he bends,
Where haue ye bene thus long out of my sight?
Much feared I to haue bene quite abhord,
Such earthly mettals soone consumed bene:
Had neuer bene, ne euer by his might
Which had approued bene in vses manifold.
Me reft from it, had bene partaker of the place.
As if in Adamant rocke it had bene pight.
As it had deawed bene with timely raine:
Which long time had bene shut, and out of hond
To haue bene wroght by that false sorceresse.
Like as it had bene many an Angels voice,
They bene ymet, both readie to affrap,
So bene they both attone, and doen vpreare
For well ye worthie bene for worth and gentle thewes.
Ye bene right hard amated, gratious Lord,
He had not trayned bene in cheualree.
They bene ybrought; he quickly does him dight,
Bene choisely picked out from all the rest,
Hath bene thy faithfull aide in hard assay,
Now bene they come, whereas the Palmer sate,
Certes, Sir knight, ye bene too much to blame,
By sea to haue bene fro[m] the Celticke mayn-land brought.
Into this land by chaunce haue driuen bene,
That nought him grieu'd to bene from rule deposed downe.
Hath long bene vnderkept, and downe supprest,
As hurt he had not bene. Thereby there lay
And had not bene remoued many a day;
He then remembred well, that had bene sayd,
And shiuered ships, which had bene wrecked late,
As if it had to him bene sacrifide;
They bene ymet, and both their points arriued,
Certes (said she) then bene ye sixe to blame,
As it in bookes hath written bene of old.
Bene in his ashes raked vp, and hid,
I weene, would you misseeme; for ye bene tall,
Bene they all dead, and laid in dolefull herse?
Soone as they bene arriu'd vpon the brim
Had she not bene deuoyd of mortall slime,
She should not then haue bene reliu'd againe,
To bene auenged of the shame, he did
Had vsed bene of that foolehardy Squire;
And thereby deemd the beast had bene depriu'd
To your disports: ill mote ye bene apayd.
To make exceeding mone, as they had bene vndonne.
As he had long bene learned to obay;
They bene agreed, and to the gates they goe
They bene ybrought into a comely bowre,
From aged Mnemon; for my wits bene light.
So bene they gone yfeare, a wanton paire
As if no trespasse euer had bene donne:
As if he had bene slombring in the shade,
As it with mightie leuers had bene tore:
Was closed vp, as it had not bene bor'd,
And oftentimes doe wish it neuer had bene writ.
With which she from her childhood had bene fed.
Forgetfull each to haue bene euer others frend.
Certes me seemes bene not aduised well,
As one whose inner parts had bene ythrild
As one that had out of a dreame bene reard,
Hauing therein bene trained many a yeare,
And had in many a battell oft bene tride,
Which else was like to haue bene lost, and bore
It hath bene through all ages euer seene,
As if he had in prison long bene pent:
With fell intent, on him to bene ywroke,
(Quoth she) of all that euer hath bene knowen:
Yet had it bene right hard him to withstand,
That them to view had bene an vncouth sight;
Betwixt him and his hurt bene happily,
All these and all that euer had bene tyde,
And had he not bene held, he nought had fayld of it.
And should haue ioyned bene to her in wedlocks knot.
In which he had bene trayned many a day,
That whylome hath of Hercules bene told,
Might else haue with felicitie bene crowned:
But want of meanes hath bene mine onely let,
That whilome in his youth had bene a Knight,
Which had bene reft from many a noble Knight;
Had shrowded bene, she did from thraldome free;
So ran they all, as they had bene at bace,
To haue bene done against her Lady Queene,
As either might for wealth haue gotten bene,
The which whylome that Ladies owne had bene;
Had bene the keye of all that kingdomes crowne;
Whereas so many knights had fouly bene fordonne.
As it had bene two shepheards curres, had scryde
They bene ymett in middest of the plaine,
She deem'd him sure to haue bene dead on ground,
As they had potshares bene; for nought mote slake
Haue trayned bene with many noble feres
But euermore contrary hath bene tryde,
Bene helped through the swiftnesse of his steed,
As if she doubted to haue bene deceiued,
And certes it hath oftentimes bene seene,
Then those, which haue bene dandled in the lap.
Where haue ye all this while bin wandring, where bene weft?
Where I had surely long ere this bene dead,
That he had bene a man of mickle name,
For whylome he had bene a doughty Knight,
Pursu'd him streight, in mynd to bene ywroken
As if he long had to his heasts bene trayned.
So now she had bene wandring two whole yeares
Else had he surely there bene slaine, or fowlyshent.
To rest my barcke, which hath bene beaten late
Had riuen bene, and all her hart strings brast,
Or how faire Pastorell should haue bene sold
That better were with them to haue bene dead,
When she was slaine, or had bene to her succour nere.
Though out of course, yet hath not bene mis-sayd,
All pau'd beneath with Iaspar shining bright,
Or low beneath, yet ought they well to know
In hope by him great benefite to gaine,
But with sweet loue and sure beneuolence,
And vnto all his creatures so benigne,
And to the ground his eyes were lowly bent,
So bent his speare, and spurnd his horse with yron heele.
O who does know the bent of womens fantasy?
Their backward bent knees teach her humbly to obay.
Each other bent his enimy to quell,
To wreake the guilt of mortall sins is bent,
For dearely sure her loue was to me bent,
Her stedfast eyes were bent, ne swarued other way.
With folded hands and knees full lowly bent
Themselues to ground with gratious humblesse bent,
On the long voyage whereto she is bent:
Against her snowy brest he fiercely bent,
But hid her visage, and her head downe bent,
For Gods deare loue be not so wilfull bent,
Whiles cursed steele against that badge I bent,
But with bent lowring browes, as she would threat,
Against him bent, and fiercely did menace:
That made him reele, and to his brest his beuer bent.
With cruell purpose bent to wreake on him
Therewith she sweetly smyld. They though full bent,
But bent his hastie course towards the idle flood.
That to a stedfast starre his course hath bent,
Both fiercely bent to haue him disaraid;
With that his balefull speare, he fiercely bent
Bent hollow beetle browes, sharpe staring eyes,
And gainst the Romanes bent their proper powre,
Headed like Owles, with beckes vncomely bent,
Their wicked engins they against it bent:
And that fourth band, which cruell battry bent,
And his mischieuous bow full readie bent,
And bent his dreadfull speare against the others head.
But for she saw him bent to cruell play,
And all the while faire Malecasta bent
For though my loue be not so lewdly bent,
Which when she saw, more bent to eke my smartes,
His bloudie speare eftsoones he boldly bent
As if he were on some aduenture bent,
The Boaster at him sternely bent his browe,
Gainst whom he alwaies bent a brasen shield,
All bent to mirth before the bride was bedded,
With speedie course, as bent to charge them new.
Who seeing both bent to so bloudy games,
Yet one of many was so strongly bent
That both were bent t'auenge his vsage base,
A mightie speare eftsoones at him he bent;
Had fild, that he to fell reueng was fully bent.
Bent to reuenge on blamelesse Britomart
That seem'd he was full bent to some mischieuous deede.
With bow in hand, and arrowes ready bent,
Then haue they all themselues against me bent:
Which I, that was not bent to former loue,
Him selfe he bent their furies to abate,
Th'one forward looking, th'other backeward bent,
In hope thereby her to his bent to draw:
And bent against them selues their cruell hands.
And countenaunce fierce, as hauing fully bent her,
The felnesse of her heart, right fully bent
Well shot in yeares he seem'd, and rather bent
Vnto the land of Amazons, as she was bent.
And euer as she rode, her eye was backeward bent.
So both together ylike felly bent,
For zeale of Iustice was against her bent.
Hastily bent, that enterprise to heare,
As three great Culuerings for battrie bent,
Gainst whom my selfe I long in vaine haue bent,
Vpon our way, to which we weren bent,
As bent to some malicious enterprise,
Did front him face to face against him bent,
Like a fierce Bull, that being busie bent
Her tyreling iade, was bent her to abuse;
And smote him on the knee, that neuer yet was bent.
It neuer yet was bent, ne bent it now,
It neuer yet was bent, ne bent it now,
On which his hungry eye was alwayes bent;
No more then for the stroke of strawes or bents:
Whose sences all were straight benumbd and starke.
Benumbd so inly, that her wits nigh fayld,
His powrelesse arme benumbd with secret feare
Benumbes her cheekes: Then out aloud she cries,
Did equally bequeath his lands in fee,
As she bequeathd in her last testament;
Forgo that royall maides bequeathed care,
Faire Amoret, whom Fortune by bequest
Had thousand women of their loue beraft,
And that knights berd for toll, which they for passage pay.
The ruefull Strich, still waiting on the bere,
He wist not how her thence away to bere;
By tortious wrong, or whom bereau'd of right.
That quite bereau'd the rash beholders sight:
To war on those, which him had of his realme bereau'd.
And made more hast, the life to haue bereau'd:
Her swollen hart her speach seemd to bereaue,
Ne wote I, but thou didst these goods bereaue
Till vengeance vtterly the guilt bereaue:
Through which she might his wretched life bereaue.
Bereaue it thence: such blot his honour blemish should.
Thus to bereaue thy Loues deare sight from thee:
That all my senses were bereaued quight:
They were through wonder nigh of sense bereaued,
Right sorrowfully mourning her bereaued cares.
And gan inquire, how was that steed bereaued,
Thinking to haue her griefe by death bereaued.
That all she sought, was mens good name to haue bereaued.
That all his senses seemd bereft attone:
She ran in hast his life to haue bereft:
There present saw, each one of sence bereft,
Hath you thus long away from me bereft?
In yron chaines, of liberty bereft,
That so rich frute should be from vs bereft;
He wrought, that thence all goodnesse he bereft,
That of your selfe ye thus berobbed arre,
That is berobbed of her youngling dere,
Then I leaue you, my liefe, yborne of heauenly berth.
Most vertuous virgin borne of heauenly berth,
But to this faire Belphoebe in her berth
Her berth was of the wombe of Morning dew,
Whilome begot, being but halfe twin of that berth.
For at that berth another Babe she bore,
And there made gods, though borne of mortall berth,
Vnto her waste, with flowres bescattered,
Thicke forest, was bescratcht, & both his feet nigh lame.
Mote I beseech to succour his sad plight,
And then those Knights he humbly did beseech,
Beseeching him with prayer, and with praise,
By all that vnto them was deare, did them beseeke.
And myld entreaty lodging did for her beseeke.
But somewhat redder, then beseem'd aright,
Gan him auize, how ill did him beseeme,
Mote Princes place beseeme so deckt to bee.
As meetest may beseeme a noble mayd;
Take here your owne, that doth you best beseeme,
Ne better doth beseeme braue cheualry,
Did her beseeme. And euer, as the crew
The knight much honord, as beseemed well,
Was clad in blew, that her beseemed well;
Who faire them quites, as him beseemed best,
Burnt I do burne. Right well beseemed it,
They did obeysaunce, as beseemed right,
But with faire countenaunce, as beseemed best,
And him saluting, as beseemed best,
Which for her sake he wore, as him beseemed well.
But foure of them the battell best beseemed,
In seemely wise, as them beseemed best:
And well beseemes all knights of noble name,
That ill beseemes thee, such as I thee see,
What euer be the cause, it sure beseemes you ill.
Him ill beseemes, anothers fault to name,
It ill beseemes a knight of gentle sort,
Faire sister, ill beseemes it to vpbrayd
Her well beseemes that Quest (quoth Satyrane)
Ne lesse in vertue that beseemes her well,
They to him hearken, as beseemeth meete,
Call me the Squyre of Dames that me beseemeth well.
And well beseemeth that in Princes hall
And him salute with well beseeming glee:
It is no lesse beseeming well, to beare
With stayed steps, and graue beseeming grace:
And sad habiliments right well beseene;
Who in her selfe-resemblance well beseene,
All were faire knights, and goodly well beseene,
All fretted round with gold, and goodly well beseene.
In glistering armes right goodly well beseene,
As tokens of her thankefull mind beseene,
Of costly Iuory, full rich beseene,
How each to entertaine with curt'sie well beseene,
Deckt with greene boughes, and flowers gay beseene.
Attonce vpon him ran, and him beset
On equall plaine, and there so hard beset;
And sore beset on euery side around,
It fortun'd whylest they were thus ill beset,
A louely Ladie rode him faire beside,
And him beside rides fierce reuenging VVrath,
And came to shamefull end. And them beside
And there beside of marble stone was built
And him beside there lay vpon the gras
There grew a goodly tree him faire beside,
Whose early foe awaiting him beside
Beside a bubbling fountaine low she lay,
And fast beside, there trickled softly downe
She set beside, laying his head disarm'd
And fast beside him sat tumultuous Strife:
Beside his head there sate a faire young man,
And them beside an aged Sire did trace,
And him beside an aged Squire there rode,
Beside Cayr Verolame, in victorious fight,
Beside those armes there stood a mighty speare,
Her bow and gilden quiuer lying him beside.
Beside the same a dainty place there lay,
Sitting beside a fountaine in a rew,
Sitting beside his mother on the ground;
In thousand shiuers, and so forth beside her past.
The which beside the gate for swine was ordered.
And him beside marcht amorous Desyre,
And eke those masked Ladies riding them beside.
Together with this Hag beside her set,
And fast beside a little brooke did pas
Sitting in shade beside his grazing steede;
Vpon a day as she him sate beside,
Whose bloudie corse they shew'd him there beside,
But one old woman sitting there beside,
But those two other which beside them stoode,
An headlesse Ladie lying him beside,
With golden hands and siluer feete beside,
But Artegall was better breath'd beside,
Whom Trompart had in keeping there beside,
Like the true saint beside the image set,
And them beside two seemely damzels stood,
Behinde, beside, before, as he it list apply.
And them beside a Ladie faire he saw,
And there beside him sate vpon the ground
With carefull hands soft footing her beside,
Sitting beside his Ladie there at ease,
Who all this while stood there beside them bound,
Beside them fed, and nipt the tender bloomes:
Old Meliboe is slaine, and him beside
Besides the endlesse routs of wretched thralles,
Besides them both, vpon the soiled gras
Besides he feard her wrath, and threatned shot
Besides subiected Fraunce, and Germany,
And them vnwares besides the Seuerne did enclose.
Besides all hope with melting eyes did vew,
Besides her golden girdle, which did fall
Besides, that more suspition encreast,
Besides the huge massacres, which he wrought
Besides her modest countenance he saw
Besides ten thousand monsters foule abhor'd
And yet besides three thousand more there were
Besides the rest dismayd, might not be nombred:
Besides a thousand more of such, as sings
Besides the double strength, which in them was:
Besides vnto themselues they gotten had
Besides the great dishonour and defame,
Besides for recompence hereof, I shall
Besides a thousand more, which ready bee
Besides, through sicknesse now so wan and weake,
Besides the losse of so much loos and fame,
Besides her countenaunce, and her likely hew,
Who now no place besides vnsought had left,
He has them now foure yeres besiegd to make the[m] thrall.
Besiegd of many foes, whom straunger
besiege her dwelling place:
Which do that sence besiege with light illusions.
Seuen yeares this wize they vs besieged haue,
Me ill besits, that in der-doing armes,
Besmeard with pretious Balme, whose vertuous might
Besmeard with smoke that nigh his eye-sight blent;
With wicked herbes and ointments did besmeare
Of that old woman tydings he besought,
Who all in rage his Sea-god syre besought,
But ere they parted, Vna faire besought
Him dearely kist, and fairely eke besought
Then Vna her besought, to be so good,
Her deare besought, to let her dye a mayd.
Besought them by the womb, which them had borne,
She them besought, during their quiet treague,
She Guyon deare besought of curtesie,
And him besought by that same sacred band
Besought that Damzell suffer him depart,
For thy great Mammon fairely he besought,
And Archimage besought, him that afford,
They her besought of fauour speciall,
Perforce their studies broke, and them besought
Which seeing good Sir Guyon, deare besought
And after her besought, well as they might,
And there with many gentle termes her faire besought.
Like as the rest, late entrance deare besought;
Besought them humbly, him to beare withal,
Which by the houres he measured, besought
Besought him his great courage to appease,
Whereat she sore affrayd, yet her besought
And pardon her besought his errour frayle,
Then her besought, as she to her was deare,
She deare besought the Prince of remedie:
Besought her to graunt ease vnto my smart,
She often prayd, and often me besought,
Whom she besought to find some remedie:
Vnto himselfe she came, and him besought,
She her besought of gratious redresse.
But rather of his hand besought to die.
To cease his outrage, and him faire besought,
But her besought to take it well in gree,
Ne doffe her armes, though he her much besought.
And earnestly besought, to wend that day
To make abode that night he greatly was besought.
He him by all the bands of loue besought,
That he besought him downe by him to sit,
Besought of courtesie in that his neede,
And often him besought, and prayd, and vowd;
And them to tell him courteously besought,
Who him besought himselfe to disattyre,
And doubting much his sence, he thus bespake;
But he her comforted and faire bespake,
And with sweet ioyous cheare him thus bespake;
Him yet againe, and yet againe bespake
And in her modest manner thus bespake;
To them approching, thus the knight bespake:
Till her that Squire bespake, Madame my liefe,
With goodly reason, and thus faire bespake;
When she at last him spying thus bespake;
Till that him thus bespake their soueraigne Lord & sire.
But roughly him bespake. Thou fearefull foole,
That sire he foule bespake, Thou dotard vile,
Till Alma him bespake, Why wonder yee
When them the wary Boateman thus bespake;
As it an Earth-quake were; at last she thus bespake.
And sighing sore, at length him thus bespake;
Conceiu'd a bold deuise, and thus bespake;
The knight approching, sternely her bespake;
And gazing each on other, nought bespake:
Then trembling yet through feare, the Squire bespake,
For thy, he thus to Paridel bespake,
All full of wrath, thus fiercely him bespake;
And charging him a fresh thus felly him bespake.
Yet nigh approching, he them fowle bespake,
He thus bespake; Certes Sir Artegall,
Her thus bespake; But Sir without offence
That being mou'd with ruth she thus bespake.
And sighing inly deepe, her thus bespake;
Then good sir Claribell him thus bespake,
Where that same Damzell lowdly him bespake,
To her bespake; Sir Knight it seemes to me,
Him thus bespake; O most redoubted Knight
At length bespake; What meanes this, gentle swaine?
Which when as he perceiu'd, he thus bespake;
Him thus bespake; My liefe, my lifes desire,
